subSubSection.paragraph:
Typhlops intermedius —
(not Jan) Schmidt, K., 1923: 47 (part, Niangara).

paragraph.treatmentCitationGroup:
Typhlops steinhousi
(sic) —
Hahn, 1980: 72
;
McDiarmid et al., 1999: 120
.

subSubSection.paragraph: Description. Snout rounded, prominent. Rostral broad, oval; frontal subhexagonal; supraocular transverse, its lateral apex between preocular and ocular; eye visible below preocular; nasal sulcus arising from first labial; SIP T-X (P, P, O, O); MSR 26–28; MD 378–430 (mean 406.6, n = 18); vertebrae 235–255 (mean 245.7, n = 18); MD/V ratio 1.60–1.74 (mean 1.65, n = 18); L/D ratio 41–44 (mean 42.3, n = 4). Dark brown above, each scale paler posteriorly, venter immaculate. Largest specimen (MNHN 1964.139—Boukoko, Central African Republic ) has a total length of 620 mm .
Distribution. Rainforest from southeastern Nigeria through Cameroon and southern Central African Republic to northeastern Democratic Republic of the Congo (Ituri Forest), 0–645 m ( Fig. 12 ).

Localities.
CAMEROON . Ajoshöhe am Nyong
ZMB 30686
B; Bitye BMNH
1946.1.23.48–50 ( syntypes of
Typhlops batesii Boulenger
), BMNH
1914.5.27.4–5; Kribi FMNH 4034
.
CENTRAL AFRICAN REPUB- LIC. Boukoko MNHN 1946.139 ( neotype of
Typhlops steinhausi Werner
)
;
La Maboké MNHHN 1963.867 , 1964.406 – 08 , coll. Pujol
462–64, 466–67, 469, 480 ( Roux-Esteve, 1974 ).
DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC OF THE CONGO . Niangara AMNH 11630–31
.
NIGERIA . Oban District BMNH 1910.2
.32.2.
